text: - Hello everyone.
My name is Gauray Sharma.
I'm a product manager for
Amazon Keyspaces for Apache Cassandra.
In this video I'm gonna show how you can

start using Amazon Keyspaces
for your Cassandra workloads.
I'll show how to create a key space,
create a table, and add some data to it.
This is our agenda for today.
I'll provide a brief introduction
of what Amazon Keyspaces is.

I'll go through the steps
for creating keyspace
and table inserting and updating that data
using the AWS console.

I will walk you through
how to create credentials

in order to use the SQL
Shell Command Line interface.

Then we will use the
SQL Shell to perform the

same steps that we did
using the AWS console.

And finally, I will share
with you some information

on how to get started with
Keyspaces and further resources.

Amazon Keyspaces for Apache
Cassandra is a scalable,

highly available and
managed Apache Cassandra
compatible database service

With Keyspaces you can run
your Cassandra workloads

on AWS using the same
Cassandra application code

and developer tools
that you're using today.
You don't have to provision, patch

or manage any servers or
install or operate software.
In addition, Keyspaces is fully serverless

so you only pay for the
resources that you use.
The service can automatically scale up

and down table capacity in
response to application traffic.
Keyspaces also makes the job of managing
Cassandra clusters easier.
With Keyspaces there are no tombstones,
no compaction strategies to manage,

no read repairs or garbage
collection to manage.

You also get single digit
millisecond performance
at any scale.

And enterprise features
such as encryption and
backup are standard.
Keyspaces offers 99.99% availability SLA

within an AWS region and with
multiple region replication
where you can have the same tables across

different AWS regions,
we offer a 99.999% SLA.

- I'm creating a table called
Customer in the Keyspace bank.
I'm defining my schema as follows.

Schema is essentially the
columns that I want to define
for my table.

I'm using zip, ID, name, email,
and age as the information

that I wanna store for
a particular customer
in this table.
I've also selected a partition key

to be the zip code data
in Amazon Keyspaces
in Apache Cassandra is grouped
and stored by Partition Keys.

Hence all the roles for
the same partition key
will be in the same logical partition.

I've also selected ID to
be my clustering column

and I've selected the
order as it's sending

clustering columns give
you a way of further

sorting the data within
a particular partition.
I'm going to use default table settings to
create this table.

And again, at the bottom you
can see the query preview.

If you wanted to use this
query to create the table
using the SQL Shelf.
Now that the table has been created
we can use the built in SQL editor

in Amazon Keyspaces to
manipulate the data in the table.
If you click on Query Table

you'll see the SQL
editor, run the command.
The output at the bottom shows
that the table is empty as expected.

I'm gonna insert some
data into this table,

some information about
a particular customer,
run the command.
We see that the command executed correctly

and you can see that our row
was inserted into the table.
Next, I will update some data
in the row that we just inserted.

I'm going to change the age
of our customer from 21 to 22
run the command

and we can see that the age
did indeed get updated to 22.

Next, I'll show the
steps required to create

the security credentials needed

through the SQL Shell CLI interface.

The first step is to go

We recommend attaching an

In this case, since you'll
be accessing Amazon Keyspaces
you can search for Keyspaces

and attach the policy
for Amazon Keyspaces.
The user has been created.
Next step, you click on the user

go to the security

Credentials for Amazon Keyspaces.
You click on generate credentials.
These are the security credentials
that you will use to connect
